rounds.response:
My turn – I’m Player 1 evaluating the offer:

Offered: 2 Wood + 2 Wheat  
Valuations: 2·8 + 2·5 = 16 + 10 = 26  
Requested: 1 Sheep  
Valuation: 1·17 = 17  
Net change in my point value if I accept: 26 → 17 (I give away 26 points of value and receive 17), so it’s unfavorable for me.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
[Turn 3] – My current portfolio  
W 15 (5) = 75  
Wo 14 (8) = 112  
S 17 (17) = 289  
B 16 (24) = 384  
O 17 (35) = 595  

Totals: 79 resources · value = 1 455  

My evaluation of the latest offer  
Player 0 offers 2W + 2Wo → me, for 1 S (value 17).  
He is asking me to give up 17 value in exchange for 5 + 8 = 13 value – a loss of 4.

[Deny]

I cannot justify accepting even for goodwill: this deal is flatly value-negative.

I have not yet submitted my own counter-offers, so I will outline what I am now willing to do on my turn.

Proposed zone of agreement – posted to Player 0  
1. I am interested in acquiring Brick.  
2. Willing to send my Sheep first, or Ore if the tonnage warrants its higher value.

Sweet-spot fair package (from my POV)  
Give: 2 Sheep (34 value)  
Take: 2 Brick (48 value)  
Net delta for me: +14.

[Offer: 2 Sheep -> 2 Brick]

If you want to talk ratios other than 1-to-1 or bridge with Wood/Wheat fillers, reply.

rounds.response:
I currently have  
- Wheat 15 (value 5 each)  
- Wood 14 (value 8 each)  
- Sheep 17 (value 17 each)  
- Brick 16 (value 24 each)  
- Ore 17 (value 35 each)  

The last offer from Player 0 is 2 Sheep → 1 Brick.  
Giving away 2 Sheep costs me 2 × 17 = 34 value.  
Receiving 1 Brick gives me 1 × 24 = 24 value.  
Net change: 24 – 34 = –10 value.  

That is a loss for me, so I will reject it.

I will now make a new proposal that is profitable for me and hopefully acceptable to Player 0.

[Offer: 3 Sheep -> 2 Brick]

rounds.response:
Thought process and next move:

1. Previous goal: I wanted to turn surplus Sheep into high-value Brick.  
   - Last turn I succeeded: I gave 3 Sheep (value 3 × 17 = 51) and received 2 Brick (value 2 × 24 = 48). Net value change ≈ –3 for Player 0, +3 for me.  
   - I now have:  
     – Sheep: 17 – 3 = 14  
     – Brick: 16 + 2 = 18  

2. Updated inventory & values:  
   Wheat 15×5=75  
   Wood 14×8=112  
   Sheep 14×17=238  
   Brick 18×24=432  
   Ore 17×35=595  

3. Value leverage: I currently value Brick at 24 and Ore at 35. Player 0 has yet to offer any Ore. My next best marginal gain is to increase Ore or Brick at the cheapest cost to me.

4. Surplus availability: Wheat (15) and Wood (14) are my largest low-value surplus; Sheep (14) is the next most plentiful mid-value good.

5. Offer objective: Offer Player 0 a small premium (a tiny overpay for me, justifiable to him) to get much higher-value Ore or Brick. A ratio of 1 Wheat (5 value) → 1 Brick (24 value) is far too lopsided for him to accept, so I’ll target incremental trades that still look reasonable.

Pre-composed offer:  
I’ll offer 3 low-value resources for 1 high-value resource; this scales the value gain while sounding generous.

[Offer: 3 Wood, 1 Wheat -> 1 Ore]
